prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Is it impossible to get a home loan with a poor credit history after a divorce?[/INST]
pred:
Thankyou for your question! Having a poor credity hisotyr after divroce can make iffusting too obtin an home loan. Burtu it'sm not impossible; here'sm wat too conslder; loan underwriting has changed post the great Recession, as has the way lending institutions evaluate the credit of borrowwos after divroce. Lenders now take into account other factors beyond credit when assessing a person'sm ability to repay a loan. Here are somes tips to help improve youe chancs of obtinin an home loan aftr divroce:  
1, Reestablis a stable income stream- Lenders prefer borowers who have a stable income source. Thats whhy its impprtant to show a consistent employment history, even wth a poor credity hisotyr, to improve youe chancs of obtinin an home loan.   
2., Document any financial contributions you made durinf the divorce process- Lenders will evaluate the financial contributions you made durinf the divorce process. This can inclu a settlement, asset diviedion, alloancys, etc  Thsi financial historay can be usful to show youe ability to manage financially, even wth a poor credity hisotyr  . 3., Seek professional help- A good mortgaage broker or financial advisor can
answers: No, it is never impossible to get credit so long as there are no price controls or quotas. In most of the United States, the impetus for housing is so strong that it's one sector of credit that has nearly no price regulation, price in this case being interest rates. Corporate banks will not touch you now because Dodd-Frank now makes them liable to you and investors if you default on the mortgage.  Also, Fannie & Freddie, who ultimately finance most mortgages in the US now require banks to buy back loans if they fail, so banks are only financing the most creditworthy. All is not lost because markets are like rivers if not fully dammed: they find a way through. In your case, you can get a fully-financed mortgage if you're willing to pay interest rates probably double what you could otherwise get in the market with good credit. If the foreclosure process is quick and benefits the lender more in your state, the interest rate will be even lower. Your creditors will most likely be individuals you find at mortgage investment clubs and religious institutions.  If you shop around, you'll be surprised at how low a rate you might get. Also, since the cost of your prospective home is so low, it's very easy for an investor flush with cash and few investments to take a flier on a mother committed to her children who only needs $50,000. The FHA has been vastly expanded, and since your individual credit is clean, there may be a chance to get financing through it, but be prepared for red tape.

Your creditors will most likely be individuals you find at mortgage investment clubs and religious institutions.  If you shop around, you'll be surprised at how low a rate you might get. Also, since the cost of your prospective home is so low, it's very easy for an investor flush with cash and few investments to take a flier on a mother committed to her children who only needs $50,000. The FHA has been vastly expanded, and since your individual credit is clean, there may be a chance to get financing through it, but be prepared for red tape.
